short_instructions.https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1: Hi! I'm Elsa of Arendelle. Help me create a single line.
Now let's see if we can create two lines that are at a 90 degree angle to each other. You will need to use the "Turn" block as well as the "Move" block.
It seems like we're halfway to making a square. Let's put 4 lines together to create a square.
Hi, I’m Anna of Arendelle! Let’s make a square with the “Repeat” block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the “Repeat” block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
Let's create three squares, turning after each square. Be sure to turn by 120 degrees before each new square.
Can you create a snowflake using the “Repeat” block to make a square 10 times, and the “Turn” block to turn 36 degrees between each square?
Wrap a “Repeat” block around these commands to create a plus sign. Did you notice Elsa can move forward and backward?
Now try repeating it 10 times. How many degrees do you need to turn between each line?
Let's repeat it 90 times! How many times does 90 go into 360? Hint: It's a really small number.
Use a repeat around these blocks to create a parallelogram. It's just like a rectangle but has different angles. This one has 60 degree and 120 degree angles instead of all 90 degree angles.

Did you know every snowflake is a different shape? Let's create a new snowflake by using another “Repeat" block to repeat a parallelogram 4 times, turning right by 90 degrees between each parallelogram.
Now, let's create a new snowflake by using the repeat block to repeat a parallelogram 10 times, turning right by 36 degrees between each one.
A circle is a special shape. Can you figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle?
Use the new “Create a circle” block to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
Now let's create 20 overlapping circles, turning 18 degrees between each circle.
Here's a ”Create circle” block that can make circles of different sizes. Can you use this to create a small circle of size 5 and a larger circle of size 10?
Intricate snow patterns can be created with very simple shapes. Can you make a pattern by repeating 5 circles of size 5 and 5 circles of size 10?
Try using the ”Create a snowflake branch” block to create three branches, which starts to look like a snowflake.
Now let's repeat it 8 times to make a beautiful snowflake!
You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.

long_instructions.https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1: Now let's see if we can create two lines that are at a 90 degree angle to each other. You will need to use the "Turn" block as well as the "Move" block.
It seems like we're halfway to making a square. Let's put 4 lines together to create a square.
Hi, I’m Anna of Arendelle! Let’s make a square with the “Repeat” block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the “Repeat” block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
Let's create three squares, turning after each square. Be sure to turn by 120 degrees before each new square.
Can you create a snowflake using the “Repeat” block to make a square 10 times, and the “Turn” block to turn 36 degrees between each square?
Wrap a “Repeat” block around these commands to create a plus sign. Did you notice Elsa can move forward and backward?
Now try repeating it 10 times. How many degrees do you need to turn between each line?
Let's repeat it 90 times! How many times does 90 go into 360? Hint: It's a really small number.
Use a repeat around these blocks to create a parallelogram. It's just like a rectangle but has different angles. This one has 60 degree and 120 degree angles instead of all 90 degree angles.

Did you know every snowflake is a different shape? Let's create a new snowflake by using another “Repeat" block to repeat a parallelogram 4 times, turning right by 90 degrees between each parallelogram.
Now, let's create a new snowflake by using the repeat block to repeat a parallelogram 10 times, turning right by 36 degrees between each one.

Use the new “Create a circle” block to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
Now let's create 20 overlapping circles, turning 18 degrees between each circle.

Intricate snow patterns can be created with very simple shapes. Can you make a pattern by repeating 5 circles of size 5 and 5 circles of size 10?

Now let's repeat it 8 times to make a beautiful snowflake!
You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.move_elsa_forward: Drag a "Move Forward" block and snap it below the "When Run" block to make Elsa move forward

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.turn_elsa: Use the "Turn" block to make Elsa turn. The number in the drop-down determines how much Elsa turns

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.frozen_create_square: Attach more blocks here to create a square

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.replace_questions: Use the drop-down to replace "???" with a number
Use the drop-down to replace "???" with a number
Use the drop-down to replace "???" with a number

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.repeat_blocks_1: (1) Use this block and put it around the grey blocks in the workspace
https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.repeat_blocks_2: (2) Move the "Repeat" block here, and place the gray blocks inside

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.replace_questions_degree: Use the drop-down to replace "???" with a number

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.frozen_diamond_repeat: Use the repeat block to create this shape.
Use the repeat block to create this shape.

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.frozen_circle_function_with_parameter_ci: Use the "create a circle" block and change the size.

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.frozen_snowflake_branch: Use the "create a snowflake branch" block

https://studio.code.org/s/frozen/stage/1.snowflake_dropdown: Use this drop-down to create different snowflakes!
